notesStmt.note: Other editions: At least three reprints.

msIdentifier.repository: Library of the Institute of Chinese Studies

physDesc.p: Illustrations: It includes graphic representations for illustrating certain entries.

msContents.p: Index: Two kinds. a) Fenlei mulu, entries firstly grouped by its category and then by stroke count. Shows the page number below. b) Index with other names. If an entry is known under an other name, it might be shown here.
Contents: Covers a broad thematic range, sciences and humanities, but also very practical themes are included.

history.p: A copy and a scan of the work is available at the library of the Institute of Chinese Studies, Heidelberg University.

settingDesc.p: The book was compiled and written by Huang Moxi, with some assistance by other scholars. The project was supported by the Society for the Preservation of National Learning.

The Chinese dictionaries company was a private institution, founded in 1902, had its greatest concentration of publishing activities between 1909-1915, primarily putted out materials to Chinese culture.

textDesc.constitution: A text divided into many short entries.
textDesc.derivation: Huang probably wrote a lot by himself, but has also copied and translated entries from other dicitionaries.
textDesc.purpose: Huang Ren shared admiration for the scholarly achievements of the West, but was deeply rooted in Chinese culture as well. With this book he wants to show that the West is an object worth studying.

encodingDesc.p: Scans available at the library of the Institute of Chinese Studies, Heidelberg University.

Digitalization by Formax BPO Beijing Inc., special instructions for typing Chinese texts and encyclopedias developed by Wolfgang Schmidle et. al. at Max Planck Institute for the History of Science, Berlin.
